Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the mother needs to correct the behavior
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story: I gripped my phone tightly, headset pressing into my ear as I paced the supermarket aisle, my son darting between displays of cereal boxes. “Yes, ma’am, our service does include free installation,” I recited, forcing a smile into my voice. My script was clear, and the customer’s questions were easy, but my eyes kept flicking to my son, who was now giggling and weaving dangerously close to a pyramid of apples. I knew I should stop him, kneel down, and explain why we don’t run indoors, why we respect public spaces. That’s what a good mother does—teaches discipline, instills values. But the call was still live, and my supervisor’s warning about call drops echoed in my mind. I was expected to be calm, professional, attentive, never distracted. My heart pounded as I tried to split myself in two, torn between the voice in my ear and the little boy who needed me right now.
